text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

IRM 1.22.1.1(5), added Primary Stakeholder information per Internal Control Requirements provided in IRM 1.11.2.2.5(4), Address Management and Internal Controls, added (6) Program Goals information per Internal Control Requirements provided in IRM 1.11.2.2.5(4), Address Management and Internal Controls
1.22.1.1.2, renamed Authority, formerly IRM 1.22.1.1.1, Governing Policy and Guidance, per IRM 1.11.2.2.5(4), Address Management and Internal Control
IRM 1.22.1.1.3, Roles and Responsibilities, formerly 1.22.1.1.1, 2.2.5(4), Address Management and Internal Controls, all subsections renumbered accordingly

IRM 1.22.1.1.3.4, Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS), formerly IRM 1.22.1.2.4(2) replaced “Project Management” with “Facilities Support”,(3) replaced “The TPOC’s responsibilities are” with “The TPOC’s responsibilities include but are not limited to”; (4) replaced “The LPOC’s responsibilities include” with “The LPOC’s responsibilities include but are not limited to”

IRM 1.22.1.1.3.6, Chief Financial Officer (CFO), formerly IRM 1.22.1.2.6, (1) removed “in the Administrative Accounting Branch of the Beckley Finance Center (BFC)”; (2) replaced “The Government Payables and Receivables Section of the Administrative Accounting Branch of the with “The Government Payables Section of the Government Payables and Funds Management office”; (3) replaced “The Funds Management Section of the Accounts Payables and Funds Management Branch” with “The Accounts Payable Financial Operations Section”
1.22.1.1.4, Program Management and Review, new section added per IRM 1.11.2.2.5(4), Management and Internal Controls
1.22.1.1.6, Frequently Used Terms and Acronyms, formerly IRM 1.22.1.1.4, Acronyms, per IRM 1.11.2.2,5(4), Address Management and Internal Controls
IRM 1.22.1.2, General Requirements, formerly IRM 1.22.1.3, renumbered per IRM 1.11.2.2.5(4), Address Management and Internal Controls, all subsections renumbered accordingly
Editorial changes have been made throughout the IRM.

Mail and Transportation Management Overview
) Purpose: This section of the IRM describes the policy requirements the Mail and Transportation Management Program. and (
) Audience: All IRS employees responsible for making decisions in either transportation management. (
) Policy Owner: The responsibility of administering the IRS Mail Program is under the direction of the Commissioner, Wage and Investment (W&I). (
) Program Owner: Distribution Requirements Branch (DRB) is the program responsible for overseeing and providing guidance for the Mail and tion Management. (

) Primary Stakeholders: The Postal and Transport Policy (PTP) section in the DRB is responsible for maintaining the Mail and Transportation ment Program. All employees who mail correspondence or ship packages, products, items or household goods are stakeholders in the Mail and tation Management Program. (
) Program Goals: The goals of this IRM is to identify and describe the overall roles of employees involved in the mail and transportation activities of the (

) The Mail and Transportation Management Program involves the control and facilitation of mail usage to meet the customers’ needs while mizing costs. Mail serves as a vital means to exchange information employees and their customers. An efficient Mail Management Program affects the relationship with taxpayers and the image and reputation with the Service. (

) Purpose: This section of the IRM describes the policy requirements the Mail and Transportation Management Program. (
) Audience: All IRS employees responsible for making decisions in either mail transportation management. (
) Policy Owner: The responsibility of administering the IRS Mail Transportation Program is under the direction of the Commissioner, Wage and Investment (W&I). (
) Program Owner: Distribution Requirements Branch (DRB) is the program responsible for overseeing and providing guidance for the Mail and tion Management. (

) Primary Stakeholders: The Postal and Transport Policy (PTP) section in the DRB is responsible for maintaining the Mail and Transportation ment Program. All employees who mail correspondence or ship packages, products, items or household goods are stakeholders in the Mail and tation Management Program. (

) The Mail and Transportation Management Program involves the control and facilitation of mail usage to meet the customers’ needs while mizing costs. Mail serves as a vital means to exchange information between employees and their customers. An efficient Mail Management Program affects the relationship with taxpayers and the image and reputation with the Service.
Purpose: This section of the IRM describes the policy requirements governing the Mail and Transportation Management Program.
Policy Owner: The responsibility of administering the IRS Mail Transportation Program is under the direction of the Commissioner, Wage and Investment
Program Goals: The goals of this IRM is to identify and describe the overall roles of employees involved in the mail and transportation activities of the IRS.

, Mail Management The responsibility of administering the IRS Mail and Transportation ment Program falls under the direction of the Commissioner, Wage and Investment (W&I). Media and Publications (M&P), Distribution (D), is the program owner for Mail and Transportation Management Program and responsible for policies for the effective use of Servicewide postal and transportation W&I Capital Management and Oversight (CMO) manages and coordinates postal and transportation budgets. The Distribution Requirements Branch (DRB) administers the Mail monitors expenditures and promotes efficient mail handling processes planning, management, direction and implementation of the full range of ties related to Mail and Transportation Management. Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) office facilitates the secure transfer of data between IRS and external partners.

Mail and Transportation Management
) The Chief Financial Officer (CFO) provides overall ﬁnancial guidance for postage and transportation funding and expenditure reporting. (

) The Distribution Requirements Branch responsibilities are: a. Develop and evaluate mail policies, systems, procedures and to help accomplish and aid the Service’s objectives Branch b. Ensure Servicewide awareness and compliance with standards and op- erational procedures established by all Mail and Transportation service providers c. Monitor the Servicewide mailings and other mail and transportation agement activities d. Implement cost-effective improvements and manage expedited mail mass mailings e. Administer the Servicewide Mail and Transportation Management Program, providing advice, guidance and standards for all IRS offices f. Serve as the principal point of contact with the USPS, the General Services Administration (GSA) and the mailing and transportation industry g. Plan, develop, administer and implement major mail management projects focusing on service improvements and compliance with laws, guidelines and best practices (

) These are accomplished by executing the following responsibilities: a. Deﬁne and keep all affected personnel informed of the objectives, policies, standards and procedures for prompt, accurate and mail operations b. Provide for continuous monitoring of mail operations throughout the Service to affect improvements as needed c. Provide liaison with the USPS and adherence to its rules, regulations practices to ensure correct, speedy and economical movement of IRS mail in the postal system d. Provide essential information to managers concerning the volume, of mail processed and postage costs e. Reduce operating and postage costs whenever possible and eliminate waste (

a. Plan, develop, administer and evaluate policies, systems, procedures standards for mail and transportation services b. Perform program and budget management for the Servicewide Mail Transportation Program, providing advice, guidance and standards for IRS offices c. Solicit and/or administer contracts, Tenders of Service and purchase agreement contracts from the small package, express services and freight carrier industry, obtaining discounted rates for use by all IRS offices d. Serve as the Agency’s liaison with the GSA and the mailing and tation services industry e. Serve as the point of contact for mail and transportation issues within Service

) Reconciliation of the USPS monthly expenditure report and its transactions a joint responsibility of the CFO, Financial Management Unit, W&I Capital Management and Oversight, and the DRB. In-depth information and and regarding W&I CMO responsibilities is provided in IRM
, Postage Ac- countability and Reporting Requirements (
) Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS) coordinates ﬁeld office mailroom operations and mail delivery services under the of the Chief, FMSS. Services (

) The FMSS National Administrative Mail Contract, Contracting Officer Repre- sentative (NAMCCOR) reports to the Facilities Support, Logistics Manager. FMSS is responsible for: a. Communicating changes in policy to the ﬁeld b. Educating and training Territory Points of Contact (TPOCs) c. Conducting program reviews (

) The Territory Manager of each territory will appoint a TPOC to provide mail management program guidance and direction to mail room operations within their servicing area. The TPOC serves as the primary point of contact with NAMCCOR. The TPOC’s responsibilities include but are not limited to: a. Implement internal guidelines for administering mail b. Direct the proper use of the classes of mail, USPS services and tive methods of shipment c. Ensure the cost-effective and proper use of various USPS services Post Office Boxes, Business Reply Mail, etc.) d. Oversee the postage expenditure reporting and direct accountability process e. Serve as liaison and consultant for the Local Point of Contact (LPOC) f. Address routine questions g. Serve as a clearinghouse for changes in mail stops h. Facilitate unidentiﬁed mail process i. Administer and monitor contractual services related to the Mail Program (

) In locations that are not serviced by the National Mail Contractor, LPOCs are assigned by the Business Operating Divisions for the receipt, distribution and sending of local and express mail. The LPOC should be knowledgeable in basic mail handling techniques and local mail problems. The LPOC serves the primary contact for the Facilities Mail Program TPOC. The LPOC’s sibilities include but are not limited to: a. Maintaining knowledge of mail management policies and guidance b. Preparing and submitting Form

-A, Postage Report c. Working with the local Postmaster to resolve local mail problems d. Adhering to the postal accountability and postage expenditure reporting requirements e. Ensuring postage is added to the postage meter as needed f. Reporting mail equipment issues and supply needs through the TPOC

Mail and Transportation (

) A key role of this office is to facilitate the transfer of data between IRS various state, city and federal agencies. This program responsibility Governmental the secure transmission of sensitive data such as tax returns and and Disclosure information, official use of information and classiﬁed information for Office Security. The security requirements are found in IRM
, Privacy and IRM
, National Security Information (NSI). (

) The Travel Management Section is responsible for: a. Counseling employees who are relocating at IRS expense Financial Officer b. Coordinating household goods transportation, storage and services relating to the employee’s move c. Assuring payment of carrier invoices for those services (
) The Government Payables Section of the Government Payables and Management office is responsible for payment of mail services provided USPS. (
) The Accounts Payable Financial Operations Section is responsible for of transportation invoices. (
) The Postal and Transport Policy Section administers the Mail Program, working closely with stakeholders to monitor expenditures related to Mail Management Transportation Management. Review (

) The reconciliation of the USPS expenditure report (OMAS Report) is a responsibility among the CMO, Distribution Requirements Branch and CARE Finance; with the support of Government Payables & Funds ment (GPFM) as needed. (

) OMAS Report - Monthly report issued by the USPS that contains postage penditures: • The CMO downloads the OMAS report each month, converts the to Excel workbook and distributes to the Agency Cost Center, Contact. • The Points of Contact review and reconcile the information, the workbook to CMO. • PTP is responsible for reconciling the M&P postage expenditures. (
) All IRS Offices (except the major cost centers) expending postage funds required to report postage purchases and expenses on a transactional Controls (
) Form
-A, Postage Purchases/Expenditure Report must be prepared submitted within ﬁve business days of purchase to M&P, DRB and GPFM veriﬁcation and entry into IFS. (
) PTP cross-checks the OMAS charges to the submitted Forms
-A. crepancies are addressed with the office responsible for the charge. (

and Transportation Management Overview 1.22.1

Terms Term Deﬁnition Mail Mail consists of letters, memoranda, post cards, documents, forms, packages, publications, computer tapes and tax data (returns and remit- tances). Official Mail Mail sent by U.S. Government agencies that relates solely to the business of the U.S. Government, authorized by law to be trans- ported in the mail without prepayment of postage. Official Mail Accounting System The postage accounting system (OMAS) of the USPS for federal govern- ment agencies. Penalty Mail Official Mail sent without the pre- payment of postage by U.S. Government Agencies. Mail must have the endorsement words “Official Business/Penalty for Private Use $300” printed on the mail. Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition

) The Private Express Statutes of
CFR
and
as amended by rules the Federal Register are a group of laws providing the USPS the exclusive right to carry letters for compensation, with certain limited exceptions. (

) Official Penalty Mail is official mail sent by the U.S. Government agencies relating solely to the business of the U.S. Government, authorized by law to transmitted in the mail without prepayment of postage. (

) The IRS must reimburse the USPS the amount of postage and fees due for penalty mail services received. The USPS requires the agencies to use postage meters (postage evidencing systems) or other forms of direct ability for penalty mail services to ensure proper reimbursement through the Official Mail Accounting System (OMAS). Detailed guidance is provided in
, Postage Accountability and Reporting Requirements.

) Agencies authorized to use penalty mail must obtain licenses or permits at speciﬁc Post Offices to use penalty postage meters, penalty permit imprints Permits and penalty business reply mail. The IRS has been granted a penalty permit by the USPS and has been assigned the Federal Agency Control Code
, Penalty Permit Imprint No. G-
and Penalty Reply Mail Permit No.
Each IRS Field Office is also assigned a Federal Agency Sub-Office cost The code is available in the current Financial Management Codes Handbook at href=https://irssource.web.irs.gov/cfo. (

) The private use of penalty envelopes, cards, cartons, labels, meter stamps, or penalty mail stamps is prohibited and may not be provided to any private person or organization, unless the use is directly related to the business of U.S. Government and permitted by USPS standards. (

) The IRS uses a centralized postage payment process for Official Penalty Mail expenditures utilizing the USPS automated system OMAS. The system is to access, collect and account for data entered from Federal agencies’ statements. The USPS bills the agencies according to data generated from OMAS. Agencies use data from OMAS to monitor postage costs.

The IRS uses a centralized postage payment process for Official Penalty Mail expenditures utilizing the USPS automated system OMAS. The system is used to access, collect and account for data entered from Federal agencies’ statements. The USPS bills the agencies according to data generated from OMAS. Agencies use data from OMAS to monitor postage costs.
